metadata.case_name: Petitioner (Private Ltd. Company) v. State of Bihar & Ors.

facts.text: Bihar Sugar Factories Control Act, 1937 (Act 7 of 1937) was in force, levying cane cess and purchase tax via notifications under s.29.
Act 7 of 1937 originally temporary until June 30, 1941, extended multiple times, last by Bihar Act 6 of 1950 up to January 30, 1955.
Bihar Act 7 of 1955 amended to extend Act 7 of 1937 indefinitely beyond June 30, 1955, came into force March 30, 1955.
Essential Commodities Act, 1955 (Central Act 10 of 1955) enacted, came into force April 1, 1955; s.16(1)(b) repealed state laws controlling production, supply, distribution of essential commodities.
Bihar Act 17 of 1963 substituted new s.29 in Act 7 of 1937 retrospectively from January 1, 1962, empowering cane cess and purchase tax up to 51 naya paise per quintal.
Notification issued October 21, 1963 under s.29 imposing cane cess and purchase tax in specified areas.
Patna High Court in A.K. Jain v. Union of India (July 4, 1966) held Act 7 of 1937 and rules unconstitutional.
Supreme Court in A.K. Jain v. Union of India affirmed High Court, holding Bihar Act provisions contrary to Sugarcane Control Order 1955 altered by Art.372.
Patna High Court followed in Sugauli Sugar Works Pvt. Ltd. v. Cooperative Development and Cane Marketing Union and Belsand Sugar Co. Ltd. v. Thakur Girja Nandan Singh.
Bihar Ordinance No.3 of 1968 promulgated January 12, 1968; s.35 similar to s.29 but max 67 paise; s.50 repealed Act 7 of 1937 with savings.
Notification under Ordinance 3 issued February 16, 1968 imposing tax.
Ordinance No.3 lapsed February 28, 1968; Ordinance No.6 of 1968 promulgated same day, s.35 with second proviso deeming tax for 1967-68 under Ordinance 3 valid from its enforcement.
Bihar Ordinance 4 of 1969 promulgated July 4, 1968; s.49 taxing provisions; s.66 validating past cess/taxes before June 25, 1968 notwithstanding court orders.

Bihar Sugarcane (Regulation of Supply and Purchase) Act, 1969 (President's Act 8 of 1969) passed August 31, 1969 during President's Rule; s.66(1) validating all past cess/taxes under state law notwithstanding court orders.
In January 1968, petitioner purchased sugarcane for its factory from allotted area growers at state-fixed price.
State sent four requisitions for cane cess and purchase tax under Act 7 of 1937, including demand notice of Rs. 1,71,543/56P for January 1968 under Bihar and Orissa Public Demands Recovery Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether Bihar Act 7 of 1937 and extensions became void after Essential Commodities Act 1955, leaving no law for levy in January 1968.
Validity of 2nd proviso to s.35 of Ordinance 6 of 1968 giving retrospective effect to tax imposition.
Whether s.35 of Ordinances 3 and 6 imposed tax only prospectively via notification.
Whether Ordinance 3 of 1968 beyond Governor's competence under Art.213 due to lack of urgency or mala fides.
To what extent Act 7 of 1937 repugnant to Central Act and repealed/altered.

petitioner_arguments.text: Bihar Act 7 of 1937, Act 7 of 1955, and notification unconstitutional per Patna HC in A.K. Jain (affirmed by SC); no law authorizing levy till Ordinance 6 of 1968.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: A.K. Jain v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: 2nd proviso to s.35 Ordinance 6 of 1968 invalid; s.35 empowered prospective notification only; cannot antedate to January 12, 1968; no notification for Jan 1-11, 1968.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hukam Chand v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Ordinance 3 of 1968 beyond Art.213 competence: no urgency, mala fide.

court_reasoning.text: Governor's satisfaction under Art.213 not justiciable; no merit in mala fides claim; academic post President's Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Necessity for Ordinance subjective to Governor (State of Punjab v. Sat Pal Dang).

court_reasoning.text: Act 7 of 1937 separable: regulation (Entry 33 Concurrent List) repugnant to Central Act, repealed from April 1, 1955 per Art.372 and s.16(1)(b); taxing provisions (Entry 52 State List) not repugnant, remained valid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Taxing provisions outside s.16(1)(b) repeal; no collision with Central Act.

court_reasoning.text: A.K. Jain and related cases concerned only regulation provisions (Entry 33), not taxing; observations confined to those points; no interweaving making whole Act invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: SC in A.K. Jain did not endorse striking down taxing parts.

court_reasoning.text: Notifications under Bihar Acts continued operative till replaced; no gap in January 1968.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tax levied with authority of law throughout.

court_reasoning.text: Validating provisions in Ordinances and President's Act 8 of 1969 retrospectively validate all past cess/taxes notwithstanding court judgments; Legislature can validate retrospectively within competence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.66(1) President's Act deems taxes valid as if Act in force at material times.

holdings.text: Taxing provisions of Bihar Act 7 of 1937 continued valid post Central Act; no repugnancy.
Governor's Ordinance power valid; no justiciable issue.
Validating Acts cure any defects retrospectively.

precedents_cited.case_name: A.K. Jain v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Held Bihar Act provisions contrary to Sugarcane Control Order altered by Art.372; confined to regulation, not taxing.

precedents_cited.relevance: Patna HC followed A.K. Jain on repugnancy.

precedents_cited.relevance: Governor's satisfaction under Art.213 not justiciable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hukam Chand v. Union of India

statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed state laws on control of production/supply/distribution; not taxing.

Bihar and Orissa Public Demands Recovery Act, 1914

outcome.summary: Petition under Art.32 challenging cane cess and purchase tax for January 1968 dismissed; taxing provisions valid, validated retrospectively; no gap in authority.

key_quotes.text: "The taxing provisions of the Bihar Act were not in any way repugnant to the Central Act or any other law passed by Parliament."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on severability and validity of tax.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding any judgment, decree or order of any court, all cesses and taxes imposed... shall be deemed to have been validly imposed..."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If the Bihar Act provides anything contrary to Rule 3(3) of the Sugarcane Control Order 1955, it must be held to have been altered in view of Art. 372."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From A.K. Jain SC, limits to regulation only.
